title: Volta a Catalunya 2023: Route, teams and everything you need to know
content:
Cyclist
Volta a Catalunya 2023: Route, teams and everything you need to know

First held in 1911, the prestigious Volta a Catalunya is the fourth oldest stage race on the calendar, even pre-dating the Vuelta a España. It slots between Milan-San Remo and Gent-Wevelgem for seven stages of typically mountainous terrain around Catalonia before the finish in Barcelona.

The 2022 Volta a Catalunya was won by Sergio Higuita (Bora-Hansgrohe) ahead of Richard Carapaz (Ineos Grenadiers) and UAE Team Emirates’ João Almeida. Higuita additionally won the mountains and youth classifications, with Kaden Groves ensuring the points jersey for BikeExchange-Jayco. It was on Stage 1 of the 2022 race that Sonny Colbrelli (Bahrain Victorious) suffered a cardiac arrest that later led to his retirement from professional racing.

Jumbo-Visma’s Primož Roglič will look to continue his hot form from Tirreno-Adriatico, lining up alongside World Champion Remco Evenepoel of Soudal-QuickStep, who starts his season here. The Volta a Catalunya also marks a return to European racing for Egan Bernal (Ineos Grenadiers) after a knee injury disrupted his start to the season.

Volta a Catalunya 2023: Key information

  • Date: 20th–26th March 2023
  • Start: Sant Feliu de Guíxols
  • Finish: Barcelona
  • Distance: 1,194km
  • UK coverage: GCN+, Eurosport 1 and 2, Discovery+

Volta a Catalunya 2023: The route

Catalonia is simultaneously one of the world’s most popular cycling destinations and an underrated race location. The 2023 Volta begins on the coast at Sant Feliu de Guíxols, just 30km from the cycling mecca of Girona, and the peloton will take in four climbs around that area before returning to finish.

Stage 2 takes the race to the Pyrenees as Vallter 2000 hosts a summit finish before Stage 3 really rips the GC apart with three big climbs, finishing up La Molina.

That’s followed by the easiest stage of the race as riders get to descend La Molina with only a couple of small climbs to ascend that day, which is a nice break before Stage 5’s big summit finish at Lo Port.

Stage 6 is a hilly one to keep things interesting before the final stage in Barcelona has, to quote Carlton Kirby, a testy finishing circuit.

Volta a Catanlunya: stage-by-stage

Stage 1: Monday 20th March, Sant Feliu de Guíxols – Sant Feliu de Guíxols, 164.5km

Be careful with these profiles, while it looks like they’re scaling Everest, those climbs’ gradients average 4%, 4%, 4% and 3.1%, it’s a warmup.

Stage 2: Tuesday 21st March, Mataró – Vallter, 165.5km

In contrast, Vallter 2000 is a certified big boy. 22.4km, 5.3% average and 12% max gradient, the race truly starts here.

Stage 3: Wednesday 22nd March, Olost – La Molina, 180.5km

Another summit finish at a ski destination and the second consecutive year as a summit finish at the Volta a Catalunya for La Molina. It’s not the hardest climb in this race but after two softeners in Coll de Coubet and Coll de la Creueta it won’t be easy.

Stage 4: Thursday 23rd March, Llívia – Sabadell, 188km

Stage 4 is the sprinters’ best chance.

Stage 5: Friday 24th March, Terres de l’Ebre (Tortosa – Lo Port) – Terres de l’Ebre (Tortosa – Lo Port), 176.5km

Fireworks at the ready, that final climb is 8.4km with an average gradient of 9% but ramps up to 20%. Can Evenepoel keep up on the steep stuff?

Stage 6: Saturday 25th March, Martorell – Molins de Rei, 183km

This is the opposite of earlier profiles, Alt de Fontpineda looks minor and is only 3km, but it’s steep, hitting up to 20% to create a select group into the final run-in.

Stage 7: Sunday 26th March, Barcelona – Barcelona, 136km

Alt del Castell de Montjuïc, aka the climb up to Montjuïc Castle in Barcelona, is only 2km with an average gradient of 4.8% but the six ascents will no doubt act as springboards for attacks for teams to get one final win from the race.

Volta a Catalunya 2023: How to watch

The 2023 Volta a Catalunya will be broadcast in 190 territories worldwide, through 33 television and digital broadcasters for two hours of live racing each stage.

UK viewers will be able to watch the Volta a Catalunya on Eurosport 1 and 2 or with a GCN+ or Discovery+ subscription. GCN+ costs £6.99 paid monthly, or £39.99 per year and Discovery+ costs £6.99 per month or £59.99 per year for sports and entertainment (for fans of shows like 90 Day Fiancé and Ghost Adventures).

Elsewhere in Europe, Eurosport will provide live images to 54 territories, with viewers in Denmark and Norway available to watch on TV2.

Worldwide coverage extends to Eurosport Asia, Claro Sports in several Latin American territories, Supersport in Africa and SSC in the Middle East and North Africa, as well as Caracol in Colombia, SBS in Australia, JSports in Japan, FloBikes in Canada and Sky Sport in New Zealand.

Volta a Catalunya 2023: Live coverage times

Stage 1

GCN+: 14:15 – 16:15
Eurosport 1: 15:15 – 17:00

Stage 2

GCN+: 14:15 – 16:15
Eurosport 1: 15:15 – 17:00

Stage 3

GCN+: 14:15 – 16:15
Eurosport 1: 15:15 – 17:00

Stage 4

GCN+: 14:15 – 16:15
Eurosport 1: 15:30 – 17:30

Stage 5

GCN+: 14:15 – 16:15
Eurosport 1: 17:00 – 17:30 (limited coverage due to live E3 Saxo Bank Classic on same channel beforehand)

Stage 6

GCN+: 14:15 – 16:15
Eurosport 2: 15:15 – 17:00

Stage 7

GCN+: 11:15 – 13:15
Eurosport 2: 12:15 – 14:15

All times GMT and subject to change by broadcasters.

Volta a Catalunya: Previous winners

2022: Sergio Higuita (BORA-Hansgrohe)
2021: Adam Yates (Ineos Grenadiers)
2020: No race
2019: Miguel Ángel López (Astana)
2018: Alejandro Valverde (Movistar)
2017: Alejandro Valverde (Movistar)
2016: Nairo Quintana (Movistar)
2015: Richie Porte (Team Sky)
2014: Joaquim Rodríguez (Team Katusha)
2013: Dan Martin (Garmin-Sharp)
2012: Michael Albasini (GreenEDGE)
2011: Michele Scarponi (Lampre-ISD)
2010: Joaquim Rodríguez (Team Katusha)

First winner: Sebastià Masdeu (1911)
Most wins: Mariano Cañardo (7)

Wins per country: Spain (60), France (11), Italy (10), Colombia (5), Belgium (3), Ireland (3), Switzerland (2), United Kingdom (2), Australia (1), Luxembourg (1), Netherlands (1), Russia (1), Ukraine (1).
